verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, "Cut for yourself two tablets of stone like the first, and I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke."
verses.comment: The LORD instructs Moses to replace the broken tablets with new ones.

verses.text: "Be ready by morning, and come up in the morning to Mount Sinai, and present yourself there to Me on the top of the mountain."
verses.comment: God repeats the command to meet at Sinai.

verses.text: "No one shall come up with you, and let no one be seen throughout all the mountain. Neither flocks nor herds shall graze in front of that mountain."
verses.comment: God's holiness requires separation.

verses.text: So Moses cut two tablets of stone like the first. And he rose early in the morning and went up on Mount Sinai, as the LORD had commanded him, and took in his hand two tablets of stone.
verses.comment: Follows closely to the Hebrew text.

verses.text: The LORD descended in the cloud and stood with him there, and proclaimed the Name of the LORD.
verses.comment: God reveals His character and presence.

verses.text: The LORD passed before him and proclaimed, "The LORD, the LORD, a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness,"
verses.comment: YHWH’s essential attributes are declared.

verses.text: "keeping steadfast love for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin, but who will by no means clear the guilty, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children and the children's children, to the third and the fourth generation."
verses.comment: The balance of mercy and justice is made clear here.

verses.text: And Moses quickly bowed his head to the earth and worshiped.
verses.comment: Moses’ response to God’s revelation.

verses.text: And he said, "If now I have found favor in Your eyes, O Lord, let the Lord go in the midst of us, for it is a stiff-necked people. Pardon our iniquity and our sin, and take us for Your inheritance."
verses.comment: Moses intercedes for the people.

verses.text: And He said, "Behold, I am making a covenant. Before all your people I will do wonders such as have not been created in all the earth or in any nation. And all the people among whom you are shall see the work of the LORD, for it is an awesome thing that I will do with you."
verses.comment: The renewal of the covenant is pronounced.

verses.text: "Observe what I command you this day. Behold, I will drive out before you the Amorite, the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite."
verses.comment: God restates His promise to give Israel the land.

verses.text: "Take care, lest you make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land to which you go, or it will become a snare in your midst."
verses.comment: Warning against alliances with pagans.

verses.text: "But you shall break down their altars, smash their pillars, and cut down their Asherim,"
verses.comment: Instructions to destroy pagan worship sites.

verses.text: "for you shall not worship any other god, for the LORD, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God."
verses.comment: Uses ‘Jealous’ as a personal, theological description.

verses.text: "Lest you make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, and when they prostitute themselves after their gods and sacrifice to their gods, and they invite you, you eat of their sacrifices,"
verses.comment: Idolatry is described as spiritual adultery in Hebrew.

verses.text: "and if you take some of their daughters for your sons, and their daughters prostitute themselves after their gods and make your sons prostitute themselves after their gods,"
verses.comment: Warns of spiritual danger in intermarriage.

verses.text: "You shall not make for yourself any molten gods."
verses.comment: Hebrew: ‘cast gods’; forbids idolatrous images.

verses.text: "You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib; for in the month of Abib you came out from Egypt."
verses.comment: Repeats the instructions for Passover.

verses.text: "All that opens the womb is Mine, all your male livestock, the firstborn of cow and sheep."
verses.comment: Acknowledges God's claim on the firstborn.

verses.text: "The firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb. If you will not redeem it, then you must break its neck. All the firstborn of your sons you shall redeem. And no one shall appear before Me empty-handed."
verses.comment: Redemption and sacrifice laws for firstborn.

verses.text: "Six days you shall work, but on the seventh day you shall rest. In plowing time and in harvest you shall rest."
verses.comment: Sabbath requirement is reiterated.

verses.text: "You shall observe the Feast of Weeks, the firstfruits of wheat harvest, and the Feast of Ingathering at the year’s end."
verses.comment: Defines the two major harvest festivals.

verses.text: "Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord GOD, the God of Israel."
verses.comment: Command for national pilgrimage feasts.

verses.text: "For I will cast out nations before you and enlarge your borders; neither will any man covet your land, when you go up to appear before the LORD your God three times in the year."
verses.comment: God promises protection during pilgrimage.

verses.text: "You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread; nor shall the sacrifice of the Feast of the Passover be left until the morning."
verses.comment: Echoes instructions from the original Passover law.

verses.text: "The best of the firstfruits of your ground you shall bring to the house of the LORD your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother's milk."
verses.comment: Firstfruits and a unique dietary law.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Write these words, for according to the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with you and with Israel."
verses.comment: Moses is commanded to write down the covenant.

verses.text: So he was there with the LORD forty days and forty nights. He neither ate bread nor drank water. And He wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the Ten Commandments.
verses.comment: The fasting period and giving of the Law.

verses.text: When Moses came down from Mount Sinai, with the two tablets of the testimony in his hand as he came down from the mountain, Moses did not know that the skin of his face shone because he had been speaking with God.
verses.comment: The word for ‘shone’ can also mean 'sent out rays'; the Latin Vulgate has 'horned.'

verses.text: Aaron and all the people of Israel saw Moses, and behold, the skin of his face shone, and they were afraid to come near him.
verses.comment: The effect of God's glory on those present.

verses.text: But Moses called to them, and Aaron and all the leaders of the congregation returned to him, and Moses spoke with them.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Moses’ role as mediator.

verses.text: Afterward all the people of Israel came near, and he gave them in command all that the LORD had spoken with him on Mount Sinai.
verses.comment: Moses delivers the commandments to the people.

verses.text: And when Moses had finished speaking with them, he put a veil over his face.
verses.comment: Paul uses this as an illustration in 2 Corinthians.

verses.text: Whenever Moses went in before the LORD to speak with Him, he would remove the veil, until he came out. And when he came out and told the people of Israel what he was commanded,
verses.comment: The veil was for the people, not before God.

verses.text: the people of Israel would see the face of Moses, that the skin of Moses' face shone. So Moses would put the veil over his face again, until he went in to speak with Him.
verses.comment: Completes the account of Moses’ radiant face.
